text: I'm Rita Koenig and I'm the European
editor for T magazine at the New York
Times I'm just finishing my apartment in
London and one of the final details
usually for me is hanging pictures I
have this Rory McEwan print of the of
the red onion that I love it's needed a
frame so he went to the lacy gallery
which is very near where I live in West
London
each frame does something different to
the picture so it takes it from being
one thing to another and obviously it's
always important to do what you have the
budget for but sometimes it's
interesting to go and do something a bit
more special and clients of mine are
often saying I can't believe the frame
is more than the picture this is very
important for the overall beauty of the
pictures this is how its framed the
frame we got in the end had its original
glass room which is lovely because it's
slightly wavy and you can see the
pattern it's like the surface of water
and then from there choosing the the mat
that it went on it was actually laid on
a piece of handmade paper
I'm really pleased with it to a certain
degree I'm not very fussy about what
goes up I mean they say that and then we
spend quite a lot of time working out
what goes in and what comes out and the
mix but when I'm looking at them I'm
looking at them as a whole so there
might be a picture that's not
particularly interesting and valuable
that works with the balance rather than
it being about all the pictures and I
like the mixture I've got some Glen
Latchford fashion photographs you know
mixed in with a watercolor that my
stepfather did and another one my
grandmother painted and old photograph I
bought in a junk shop so there's
definitely a sort of no rhyme or reason
really to why things go together
the lovely thing about framing is you
can buy a funny old photograph in a junk
shop or a blue watercolor somewhere and
if you love the picture you then have
something that's you totally unique to
you incredibly special and will always
make you think of that journey you took
that's the point I think of all of this
you
